parts: Research into the social, political and economic situation in Japan covering the period after the year 2000 to the present, but focussing more effort on the post-COVID period. Gather significant details and analyze their impact on Japanese society. Also address the question: What factors likely led to election of right wing candidate Takaichi Sanae as Japan's new prime minister in October this year?

To begin the research effectively, could you please confirm the following:

1. When you mention "October this year," are you referring to October 2025? As of now, Takaichi Sanae has not officially been elected Prime Minister, so I want to confirm whether you're referring to a hypothetical, projected, or fictional scenario.
2. Should the research focus on:
   - Internal social trends (e.g. aging population, gender roles)?
   - Political developments (e.g. party shifts, foreign policy)?
   - Economic aspects (e.g. inflation, employment, growth sectors)?
   - Or all of the above with balanced depth?
3. Do you have a preferred format for the output? (e.g., a structured report with headers, bullet points, or continuous prose?)

Once I have this information, I’ll start the research right away.
Yes Oct 2025. She has been elected as per latest news announcements. Output mainly in continuous prose.

Understood. I will analyze the social, political, and economic developments in Japan from 2000 to the present, with a particular focus on the post-COVID period. I’ll also investigate and explain the likely factors that led to Takaichi Sanae’s election as Prime Minister in October 2025.

I’ll return with a comprehensive analysis in continuous prose format.

parts:
# Japan’s Social, Political, and Economic Landscape Since 2000 (Focus on Post-COVID)

## Social Changes and Challenges in Post-2000 Japan  
Japan’s society has undergone significant shifts since 2000, with many trends accelerating in the post-COVID era. A defining challenge is Japan’s **demographic decline** – the population is both shrinking and rapidly aging, leading to labor shortages and straining the social welfare system【25†L1-L4】. Birth rates have plummeted to historic lows: in 2024 the country saw only **686,000 births**, the fewest since record-keeping began in 1899【13†L172-L180】. The fertility rate fell to just **1.15** (far below the 2.1 replacement level)【13†L181-L189】. This longtime trend of delayed marriage and smaller families was exacerbated by economic uncertainties and the pandemic, as many young people feel pessimistic about marrying or raising children amid poor job security and a rising cost of living【13†L225-L233】. Consequently, Japan’s total population (about 124 million in 2025) has started shrinking faster than expected, a “**silent emergency**” in the words of former Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba【13†L212-L220】. Projections warn it could fall to around **87 million by 2070**, with 40% of citizens over 65【13†L205-L213】. Such a dramatic demographic shift carries dire implications for the economy and even national security, as a smaller working-age base must support the elderly and the nation looks to maintain its military strength【13†L210-L218】.

In response, governments have launched numerous pro-family policies, especially post-COVID, but with limited success. Leaders from Fumio Kishida to Shigeru Ishiba have raised alarms that the low birthrate threatens Japan’s ability “to **function as a society**”【13†L219-L227】. They expanded child allowances, made high school education free, and even guaranteed up to 100% of take-home pay for couples taking parental leave together【13†L213-L221】. These measures, however, have yet to reverse the decline【13†L225-L233】. Critics argue the focus on married couples overlooks root causes – many young Japanese remain single, discouraged by economic prospects and a corporate culture that is unfriendly to working mothers【13†L225-L233】. Indeed, surveys show few teens are confident they will marry at all. Post-pandemic, the **social impact** of these trends is becoming more visible: rural areas are emptying out as youth migrate to cities, elder care burdens are increasing, and schools are consolidating or closing due to lack of children. Japanese society is gradually adapting with changes such as higher senior workforce participation and discussions on accepting more foreign workers, but change is slow. The COVID-19 pandemic itself, while primarily a health and economic crisis, also influenced social behavior – for example, it normalized **remote work** and online services to a degree, challenging the long tradition of long commutes and in-office presence. Many companies introduced telework during 2020 out of necessity, and although Japan has partly reverted to old work styles, there is a lasting awareness of work-life balance and digital connectivity in everyday life. The pandemic also accelerated the adoption of digital tools in daily transactions (from e-commerce to cashless payments) and reduced some social stigma around flexible schedules【15†L129-L137】【16†L1-L4】. These subtle shifts hint at a society cautiously modernizing under pressure – balancing its deep-rooted cultural norms with the need to address urgent demographic and social issues.

## Economic Developments and Trends (2000–2025)  
Economically, Japan in the 2000s and 2010s struggled to emerge from the **“Lost Decades”** of stagnation that began in the 1990s. After an asset bubble burst in the early ’90s, growth remained anemic and deflation persisted for years【9†L478-L486】. Even by the late 2000s, prices and wages were stuck or declining. A succession of governments tried stimulus measures – notably **“Abenomics”** in the 2010s under Prime Minister Shinzo Abe – which combined easy money, fiscal spending, and structural reforms to jolt the economy. Abe’s policies did spur some growth and record stock market highs, and he famously promoted tourism and corporate investment as new drivers【22†L56-L65】【22†L69-L77】. However, fundamental challenges remained. One was the huge public debt: Japan’s government debt swelled to about **260% of GDP** (by far the highest in the OECD) as of the early 2020s【9†L481-L489】【9†L492-L499】. Another was wage stagnation – remarkably, average pay in Japan only surpassed its 1997 level for the first time in 2024【8†L179-L187】. In other words, an entire generation saw nearly flat incomes, contributing to consumer caution and inequality. The aging population also hurt economic vitality: as the workforce shrinks, labor shortages in many industries limit growth【25†L1-L4】. Japan’s population peaked in 2010 and has since lost roughly 6 million people, directly undermining domestic demand and innovation capacity【9†L492-L499】. In the long run, fewer workers and more retirees put heavy pressure on pension and healthcare systems, requiring either higher taxes or significant productivity gains to maintain living standards.

**Post-COVID economic picture:** The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 delivered a sharp blow to Japan’s economy, which contracted as lockdowns and supply chain disruptions hit. The government rolled out massive stimulus packages, adding to the debt but cushioning the fallout. By 2021–22, recovery was underway, but new issues emerged. For the first time in decades, **inflation** returned – consumer prices in recent years have risen about 2.5–3%, finally above the Bank of Japan’s longstanding 2% target【8†L177-L184】. Global factors like supply shocks and the war in Ukraine pushed up energy and food costs, which Japan (as a major importer) felt acutely【11†L743-L752】. The central bank ended its experiment with negative interest rates in 2024, yet unlike other countries raising rates to tame inflation, Japan has cautiously kept rates low to ensure price rises are sustained after decades of deflation【11†L743-L752】【11†L749-L757】. One side effect has been a **weak yen** – the currency hit a 37-year low of around ¥160 per US dollar in 2024【11†L749-L757】. This yen weakness makes imports pricier (hurting consumers via higher gasoline and grocery costs) but has benefitted exporters and helped fuel a boom in **post-pandemic tourism**. After Japan fully reopened its borders in late 2022, inbound travel bounced back dramatically. By mid-2024, Japan was receiving over 3 million foreign visitors per month, exceeding pre-pandemic levels – a surge driven in part by the yen’s depreciation making Japan a bargain destination【22†L75-L83】【22†L165-L173】. Tourism has thus re-emerged as a vital economic sector, providing jobs and regional development, which was a strategic goal of pre-pandemic policy makers【22†L56-L65】.

Despite these positive signs, the **standard of living** for many Japanese remains under strain. Inflation, though moderate, is outpacing wage growth, meaning real incomes are declining for consumers. Years of labor market liberalization have left many workers in non-regular jobs with lower pay and benefits, contributing to a poverty rate around 15% (one of the highest among developed nations). Inequality has inched up, especially between older, asset-rich Japanese and younger generations who have known only economic stagnation. The pandemic amplified some of these disparities – for instance, those in secure jobs weathered it well while many part-timers and small businesses suffered disproportionately. The government under Prime Minister Fumio Kishida acknowledged these issues and championed a “New Capitalism” agenda to redistribute wealth (through higher corporate pay and social spending), but tangible results were limited. Heading into the mid-2020s, Japan’s economic priorities have shifted to managing this delicate balance: **boosting growth and productivity** (through innovation, digitalization, and perhaps mild immigration) while also ensuring that ordinary people see the benefits in their wages and well-being. The new prime minister in 2025, Sanae Takaichi, has pledged continuity in pro-growth policies – such as **easy credit and big fiscal outlays** – even as she faces the reality that Japan’s debt and demographic headwinds make long-term robust growth hard to achieve【8†L161-L169】【8†L219-L227】. Indeed, Takaichi is expected to follow her mentor Abe’s playbook (“**Sanaenomics**,” as it’s dubbed): keep interest rates ultra-low to spur investment, pour money into favored sectors like defense, and attempt structural fixes for the demographic crunch【8†L179-L187】【8†L229-L237】. How effectively these economic strategies can overcome the structural challenges remains an open question, but they will heavily influence Japanese society – determining job opportunities, social stability, and Japan’s role in the global economy – in the years to come.

## Political Landscape Since 2000  
Japan’s political scene since 2000 has been characterized by relative **stability of ruling parties** but frequent leadership changes, until recently. The conservative **Liberal Democratic Party (LDP)** has dominated governance for most of this period (as it has for most of the postwar era), with only a brief interruption. In the late 2000s, public frustration with economic stagnation and scandals allowed an opposition coalition (the DPJ) to take power from 2009 to 2012 – a historic moment ending decades of unbroken LDP rule. However, the DPJ government struggled (grappling with the 2011 earthquake/tsunami disaster and unpopular reforms), and by 2012 the LDP returned to power under Shinzo Abe. Abe’s 2012–2020 tenure brought an unusual stretch of stability: he became Japan’s longest-serving Prime Minister, implementing his economic agenda and taking a more assertive stance in foreign policy. Abe pushed for revising Japan’s pacifist constitution to enable a stronger military, a goal supported by conservatives, though he never achieved a formal amendment. He also cultivated a close alliance with the U.S. and took a hard line on issues like North Korea’s missile tests and China’s maritime activities. Domestically, Abe’s era saw a resurgence of LDP’s confidence, but it was not without controversy – there were cronyism scandals and public debates over his nationalist rhetoric and handling of history issues. Nonetheless, the political opposition remained fragmented and weak, allowing LDP (in coalition with the smaller Komeito party) to handily win elections. 

After Abe abruptly resigned in 2020 (due to health reasons), Japan saw a rapid turnover of leaders during the COVID crisis. Yoshihide Suga (2020–2021) oversaw the initial pandemic response and the delayed Tokyo Olympics (held in summer 2021 without spectators), but his public approval plummeted over perceptions of a slow COVID response and he lasted only a year. **Fumio Kishida** took over LDP leadership and the premiership in late 2021 with a relatively moderate image. Kishida’s government navigated Japan through the later pandemic stages and the global impacts of the Ukraine war. He notably improved relations with South Korea in 2023 by settling some historical disputes, and he committed Japan to a more robust defense posture (in 2022 his government announced plans to boost defense spending to 2% of GDP within five years, signaling a break from Japan’s longstanding 1%-of-GDP norm). However, Kishida faced domestic headwinds. Inflation and the weak yen began hitting consumers in 2022–2023, undermining his pledge to create a more equitable economy. Moreover, a scandal involving LDP politicians’ ties to the Unification Church (a controversial sect) — revealed after the shocking **assassination of Shinzo Abe in 2022** — tarnished the party’s image and led to several cabinet resignations. By 2023, Kishida’s approval ratings had fallen, and the LDP suffered setbacks in by-elections and local polls. 

Political developments came to a head in **2024–2025**. The LDP-led coalition lost its outright majority in the powerful Lower House of Parliament (possibly in a 2024 general election), weakening its grip on power【5†L2196-L2204】. Kishida either stepped down or was defeated in an internal party vote – in the turmoil, veteran LDP figure **Shigeru Ishiba** briefly assumed leadership. Ishiba, a one-time rival of Abe known for his own conservative views but reformist rhetoric, became prime minister. Under his short tenure, the LDP saw **“disastrous losses”** in the July 2025 Upper House elections, prompting Ishiba’s resignation in September 2025【4†L25-L34】. This paved the way for **Sanae Takaichi** to win the LDP presidency on October 4, 2025, and hence become Japan’s new Prime Minister【4†L29-L34】. Notably, Takaichi is the first woman ever to hold Japan’s top office, marking a historic moment in a country where politics has been overwhelmingly male-dominated. Her rise reflects a **rightward shift** within the LDP at this juncture: Takaichi is an “ultraconservative” and security hawk, and her victory signaled the party’s turn to a more hardline stance after the perceived centrism of Kishida and the turbulence under Ishiba【5†L2191-L2199】【24†L61-L69】. However, this shift had immediate consequences for coalition politics. The LDP’s longtime junior partner, **Komeito** (a pacifist-leaning party backed by a Buddhist movement), split from the coalition in protest – ending a partnership that had lasted since 1999【5†L2258-L2264】【24†L63-L71】. Losing Komeito’s 32 Lower House seats meant the LDP alone lacked a majority, creating an unprecedented scenario in modern Japanese politics: the dominant party needed a new ally or risk losing power.

Takaichi responded by forging a new **coalition with the Japan Innovation Party (Nippon Ishin no Kai)**, a right-leaning, Osaka-based party that shares many of her nationalist and neoliberal views【5†L2258-L2264】【24†L78-L86】. Ishin’s emergence as a “**second LDP**” in recent years – appealing to conservative voters disenchanted with the establishment – made it a logical partner once Komeito walked away【24†L78-L86】. Together, LDP and Ishin control 351 seats across both houses, which allowed Takaichi to win the parliamentary vote for Prime Minister in October 2025【24†L69-L77】. The opposition camp, while sizable in total, remains fragmented among multiple parties (ranging from the moderate Constitutional Democrats to the Japanese Communist Party), and they could not unite to offer a credible alternative【5†L2248-L2255】. This disunity among opposition forces once again enabled the LDP to remain in power by cobbling together a coalition, even after significant electoral losses. **Japanese society**, for its part, has shown mixed reactions to these political shifts. Voter turnout has been lukewarm in recent elections, reflecting a degree of apathy or disillusionment, especially among younger voters who feel their voices aren’t heard. At the same time, there is a cautious hope that a new leader – particularly a historic female PM – might reinvigorate the political landscape. Many Japanese value stability and have defaulted to the LDP’s long rule, but there is also evident frustration with the “political stagnation” and an appetite for change【5†L2238-L2244】. Takaichi’s ascent thus comes at a complex moment: her mandate is tenuous and Japan’s electorate is watching to see if she can deliver results or if another rapid turnover is on the horizon. 

## Post-COVID Societal and Policy Shifts  
The COVID-19 pandemic (2020–2022) served as a **turning point** that prompted Japan to confront long-pending issues in new ways. In governance and business, it accelerated **digital transformation**. The crisis exposed how far behind Japan’s bureaucratic systems were – for instance, health officials were initially faxing case reports, and schools struggled to move classes online【20†L1980-L1988】. Reacting to these shortcomings, the government created a dedicated **Digital Agency** in 2021 to modernize public services【20†L1985-L1993】. This agency embarked on streamlining antiquated procedures: moving more applications and records online, unifying local government IT systems, and promoting the use of Japan’s “My Number” digital ID for accessing services【20†L1999-L2007】【20†L2004-L2012】. The pandemic essentially jolted Japan into embracing e-governance and tech reforms that had been talked about for years. In the private sector, COVID-19 pushed many companies to adopt telework and flexible hours. While not all of these practices persisted (traditional work culture is deeply ingrained), a portion of the workforce has continued working remotely or in hybrid modes, a novelty in Japan’s once rigid office culture. This has had subtle societal impacts: urban commuter congestion eased during the pandemic and has not fully returned to pre-2020 levels, and people have found more time for family or personal pursuits, potentially contributing to quality-of-life improvements. The pandemic period also saw **behavioral changes** such as ubiquitous mask-wearing, heightened public health awareness, and a big shift towards cashless payment and online shopping – habits that have, to an extent, lasted beyond the immediate crisis【15†L130-L137】【16†L1-L4】. These changes indicate a society that proved adaptable when pressured, and some of the efficiency gains (like digital services) are now helping Japan tackle its other challenges (for example, telemedicine trials to support healthcare in aging rural areas, or online grocery services for the elderly). 

Economically, the pandemic’s legacy is a double-edged sword. On one hand, it induced reforms and new growth areas (such as the boost in domestic tech solutions, and the eventual rebound in consumption once restrictions lifted). On the other, it left a heavier debt load and **widened disparities**. By 2025, analysts note that inequality has increased in many countries including Japan, as asset owners and large firms bounced back quickly, whereas many small businesses and low-income workers have not fully recovered【15†L130-L137】. The government’s massive spending helped avoid a complete collapse, but now it faces the task of fiscal consolidation at some point without derailing the recovery. Socially, Japan managed the pandemic relatively well in terms of public health (its COVID death rate remained lower than most Western nations, partly thanks to cultural mask use and an obedient public response to guidelines), but at the cost of prolonged isolation – Japan kept its borders closed to tourists and even many foreign residents until late 2022. This isolation hurt sectors like tourism and entertainment severely; their comeback in 2023–2024 has been a relief but also a reminder of how globalized Japan’s economy had become. Education, too, was impacted: students endured periods of remote learning, prompting renewed discussion on work-life balance and youth mental health. The government has since been investing in resilient infrastructure (like better broadband access nationwide) to ensure preparedness for any future crises. In summary, the post-COVID period in Japan is marked by a cautious recovery and a resolve to tackle long-term issues – from digitization to demographic decline – with a new urgency born from the lessons of the pandemic. Japanese society, often perceived as slow to change, demonstrated that it could adapt rapidly when necessary, and that momentum is now being directed toward modernizing the country for a post-pandemic world.

## Factors Behind Sanae Takaichi’s Election as Prime Minister (October 2025)  

【28†embed_image】 *New Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi (center) during the Diet session that elected her in October 2025, following a tumultuous period for Japanese politics.*  

Takaichi’s rise to the premiership in October 2025 – as a hard-right candidate and Japan’s first female prime minister – was the product of several converging factors. First, there was **political fallout from prior leadership**. The ruling LDP’s popularity had been eroded by a “series of scandals in recent years” that damaged public trust【24†L58-L66】. These included allegations of corruption, the Unification Church controversy, and missteps by Kishida’s administration (such as his own son’s impropriety and ministers resigning over gaffes). Voter dissatisfaction translated into **electoral setbacks**: the LDP “suffered disastrous losses” in the July 2025 upper house elections and had already lost its outright majority in the lower house in 2024【5†L2196-L2204】. Such defeats were unprecedented for the long-dominant party, and they forced the incumbent Prime Minister, Shigeru Ishiba, to resign in order to take responsibility【4†L17-L24】【4†L25-L34】. In the LDP’s October 4, 2025 leadership contest to replace Ishiba, party members gravitated toward Takaichi, signaling a decision to double-down on a more **ideologically right-wing course**【24†L61-L69】. This can be seen as a reaction to the LDP’s losses – a belief that a more hawkish, decisive leader might shore up the conservative base and differentiate the party amid voter frustration. Takaichi, known as an **“ultraconservative” and security hawk**, had long been a protege of the late Shinzo Abe and shared his agenda of a strong defense and traditionalist social policies【5†L2202-L2209】【5†L2273-L2281】. Her victory thus represented the LDP rank-and-file embracing Abe’s legacy and a tougher image in hopes of regaining momentum.

Another crucial factor was the national **security environment and public sentiment**. By 2025, regional threats – North Korea’s missile tests, China’s military expansion – as well as global geopolitical shifts made security a top concern in Japan. Takaichi had been outspoken about bolstering Japan’s defenses and standing firm in alliance with the United States【5†L2191-L2199】【5†L2202-L2209】. She even emphasized, in her first speech as LDP leader, the need to “build a strong country” and cited the U.S.–Japan alliance as the cornerstone of foreign policy【5†L2191-L2199】【5†L2202-L2209】. This resonated with many conservative lawmakers (and voters) who felt Japan needed a tougher stance. The fact that the U.S. President by late 2025 is Donald Trump (per news context) may have also underscored the importance of having a like-minded, assertive Japanese leader to manage that alliance. Indeed, Takaichi’s alignment with Trump-era politics – she planned to host President Trump soon after taking office – positioned her as someone who could navigate the relationship much as Abe did【5†L2191-L2199】【5†L2207-L2215】. Thus, **external pressures** likely bolstered her appeal: she promised a resolute approach to defense, which, given the worries about China and an aging population’s effect on future security, seemed timely. One might say the electorate (or at least the LDP electorate) in 2025 was in a more hawkish mood, prioritizing national strength in uncertain times.

Also instrumental were **party dynamics and coalition math**. Takaichi did not lead the LDP to a landslide popular victory; rather, she was elevated by the party and then had to secure her position via a coalition deal. When the LDP’s moderate ally Komeito defected due to her hardline stances, Takaichi swiftly reached out to the right-wing **Nippon Ishin no Kai** party. Embracing Ishin was crucial – without it, the LDP risked losing power. Ishin, which held 54 seats, actually gave the new bloc a larger combined seat count than the old LDP-Komeito pairing【24†L73-L81】【24†L75-L83】. Ideologically, this was a comfortable fit: Ishin shares Takaichi’s enthusiasm for constitutional revision and a hawkish defense policy, and even opposes large immigration inflows similar to her views【24†L78-L86】. By agreeing to a policy platform with Ishin, Takaichi managed to present a viable government to parliament. Thus one can argue she was chosen *because* she could unite the right – both within her party and with an external partner – at a moment when the center had fallen out. In the parliamentary vote on Oct. 21, 2025, Takaichi won a majority in the Lower House (237 votes, just over the 233 needed) and prevailed in the Upper House in a run-off, defeating the opposition’s candidate【24†L44-L53】. Notably, the **opposition’s disarray** was a factor here: opposition parties, ranging from left to centrist, could not coordinate and thus split their votes, enabling Takaichi to secure the premiership even though her coalition was short of an absolute majority in the first round【24†L49-L57】【5†L2248-L2255】. In short, Takaichi’s election was as much about the LDP staying in power through coalition-building as it was about any popular mandate for her personally.

Finally, one cannot ignore the symbolic and strategic element of her being a **female leader**. While Takaichi herself is not a proponent of feminist policies (she is against measures like allowing married couples separate surnames or legalizing same-sex marriage【5†L2214-L2222】【5†L2223-L2231】), the fact that she is a woman breaking the highest glass ceiling in Japan could have slightly boosted the LDP’s image. After decades of male premiers and a poor record on gender parity, the LDP choosing Takaichi signaled a desire to project a *new face* to the public without drastically changing its ideology. Some voters and lawmakers likely found the idea of the first female PM **“epoch-making”**, hoping it might refresh Japan’s international image and appeal to voters craving something different【5†L2229-L2237】. This doesn’t mean Takaichi was selected because of her gender – her credentials lie in her right-wing pedigree and Abe faction backing – but it was a *convenient* bonus for a party in need of rejuvenation. As one 62-year-old Tokyo resident noted while celebrating her win, he hoped that her premiership would at last “start to move” the long-static politics and improve things in Japan【5†L2237-L2244】. Thus, the **convergence of internal LDP politics, public mood on security, coalition arithmetic, and a touch of reformist symbolism** all likely led to Sanae Takaichi’s election as Prime Minister in October 2025. Her mandate now is to address the very social, economic, and political challenges described above – from the post-COVID economic recovery to the demographic crisis – under the scrutiny of a public that is eager to see results after years of drift. Whether her hard-right leadership will provide the solutions Japan needs, or simply the latest chapter in its revolving-door politics, remains to be seen, but the factors that brought her to power underscore a nation at a crossroads, seeking a path forward in decidedly uncertain times. 

**Sources:** Japan’s declining birthrate and demographic measures【13†L172-L181】【13†L214-L222】; economic conditions and “Sanaenomics” policies【8†L177-L184】【8†L229-L237】; political shifts and Takaichi’s coalition deal【5†L2196-L2204】【24†L69-L77】; context on Takaichi’s ideology and the LDP’s rightward turn【5†L2202-L2209】【24†L61-L68】; quotes and details from Associated Press, *The Guardian*, and *TIME* reporting as cited above.

metadata.title: What to expect for Japan's economy under Sanae Takaichi, its 1st female prime minister

metadata.title: What’s behind Japan’s post-pandemic tourism surge? - CEIAS
metadata.text: In the post-pandemic era, tourism has continued positive momentum. As of May 2024, Japan is welcoming in excess of 3 million foreign tourists monthly, around 8% above the pre-pandemic level (see Chart 2). Japan attracted 31 million tourists between July 2023 and June 2024, exceeding the government’s initial targets. Across the Asia Pacific, Japan is the best-performing market in terms of visitor arrivals now compared to  2019, with most other economies still struggling to normalize (see Chart 3).

metadata.title: What’s behind Japan’s post-pandemic tourism surge? - CEIAS
metadata.text: While Japan has long been an attractive tourist destination, the weak yen is the biggest cyclical driver of post-pandemic tourism recovery. Since December 2019, it has depreciated 44% against the US dollar and 26% in the nominal effective exchange rate (NEER) term, measuring against a basket of currencies weighted by trade partners (see Chart 11). The favorable exchange rate has made trips to Japan more affordable, fuelling the post-COVID tourism boom.

metadata.title: What’s behind Japan’s post-pandemic tourism surge? - CEIAS

metadata.text: TOKYO (AP) — Share prices have soared recently in Tokyo on hopes that conservative Japanese lawmaker Sanae Takaichi, who was chosen Tuesday to be Japan’s first female prime minister, will double down on market friendly policies, including hefty spending on defense and cheap credit.

metadata.title: What to expect for Japan's economy under Sanae Takaichi, its 1st female prime minister
metadata.text: Takaichi is expected to emulate the policies of her late mentor, former Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. He stepped down in 2020 and was assassinated in 2022. His “Abenomics” approach included promises of cash handouts and boosting government spending, despite a national debt that is nearly triple the size of the economy.

Wages remain near the level they were at 30 years ago, only topping the 1997 average level in 2024 for the first time. Meanwhile, low rates have helped to keep the Japanese yen weak against the dollar, amplifying inflation since much of what Japan consumes is imported.

content_references.title: What’s behind Japan’s post-pandemic tourism surge? - CEIAS
content_references.snippet: In the post-pandemic era, tourism has continued positive momentum. As of May 2024, Japan is welcoming in excess of 3 million foreign tourists monthly, around 8% above the pre-pandemic level (see Chart 2). Japan attracted 31 million tourists between July 2023 and June 2024, exceeding the government’s initial targets. Across the Asia Pacific, Japan is the best-performing market in terms of visitor arrivals now compared to  2019, with most other economies still struggling to normalize (see Chart 3).

content_references.title: What’s behind Japan’s post-pandemic tourism surge? - CEIAS
content_references.snippet: While Japan has long been an attractive tourist destination, the weak yen is the biggest cyclical driver of post-pandemic tourism recovery. Since December 2019, it has depreciated 44% against the US dollar and 26% in the nominal effective exchange rate (NEER) term, measuring against a basket of currencies weighted by trade partners (see Chart 11). The favorable exchange rate has made trips to Japan more affordable, fuelling the post-COVID tourism boom.
